comments.commentBody: As the parent of someone currently being tested for ADHD, I have been thinking about this subject a lot.  It's hard to know what's right.  My child actually seemed to have great powers of concentration at a young age.   But something shifted when she started school, where her energy, curiousity and desire for hands-on learning began to get her in trouble.  Throughout kindergarten, her teacher complained to me at every parent/teacher meeting that she was not raising her hand before speaking, and by the end of the year it was clear that the teacher disliked her for it and that the other students knew it.  Creative minds are always exploring, shifting, imagining, and responding to stimuli.  But school rewards the opposite--performing as instructed, being handed the materials you must work with (and that goes for extracurricular activities as well). I think our educational system is still rooted in an old industrial model and has failed to keep up with the increasingly sophisticated social and emotional environment that children develop within now from the earliest age.  We are still teaching them in ways that are more suited to controlled, obedient dronehood, which is not what our culture is about today.   So you get more kids struggling to stay focused, getting frustrated, being labeled, completely dreading the unchanging routine, and learning to tune things out as a way of coping.

Where is the logic? If immigrants bring prosperity, then where is the prosperity resulting from the famous 11 million illegal immigrants? On the other hand, would the removal of 11 million illegal immigrants cause financial disaster? Frankly, I want to see the existing immigration policies enforced - and enforced with enough funding to allow for proper, business-like enforcement avoiding delays and errors in processing, the sort of errors that admit terrorists as 'refugees' that could be prevented by better checks. I want to see proper visa enforcement - especially in the area of 'skilled' worker visas which are abused and under-enforced. Visa tracking like other modern nations should be in place, too. As we already have laws in place covering these things I don't understand why we can't exercise them. THEN we can talk about changes. But not until then.

@Tom Scharf:  I'm sorry to say I think your categorization is simple-minded.  There is no reason a person who has lived with a lot of risk has to like risk.  Most such people would be glad to get rid of the risk, but they can't.  (If you don't believe me, ask why someone should believe you.)  There is no emotional reason that a person living with risk should be glad to increase it, nor that a person living with little risk should be afraid to increase it.  People are not all like you or me.

In case you didn't know, a week ago, Australia reported that unemployment hit a 10 year high - while in the US it is on the way down.

Be careful with the examples you pick.

CC - Germany has universal, government run health care, free higher education, better pensions, strong unions which are represented on the board of directors of major corporations, etc., etc., etc.

AND they are about to introduce a minimum wage.

http://www.thelocal.de/20131121/germany-to-introduce-minimum-wage
Baron - Our unemployment is still 12% above that of Australia.

Like the legendary "too small stimulus" the raise might be too small.
Raise it like in Australia up to 15 Bucks and the "benefits" would be much higher -(at least for "the people"!)

Thank you Mr Franco for your explanatory and supportive email of Mr. LaBeouf. Indeed your reference and critique relative to M. Brando provides a clear example of what Mr. LaBeouf is not doing. Brando's actions were about the control of his personality. I interpret Mr. LaBeouf's as cultural critique. Any contemporary creative individual who is adequately academic confronts such issues that Mr La Beouf brings forward: media, (profit, risk, ROI) creative authenticity ("what can i create that is truly new?"), economic disparity (thinking of his humble origins: does he think he merits the millions now? for what?)

One has simply to look at contemporary artists, 21st century artists to see the same ideas and forms of expression that Mr. LaBeoef has undertaken. Goto P.S. 21, or Performance Art as it occurs around the city and you'll see lots of similar acts.

the best evaluation of Mr LaBeoef's recent transformation is at: www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/10628273/Shia-LaBeouf-Is-there-genius-i...

All in all, Shia may just be another socially aware and driven-against-the-machine Millennium Generation kid. If so, i hope more actors join his ranks.

I get that constant media scrutiny is oppressive, but I don't think acting like a fool or plagiarizing another person's work is a particularly meaningful act of artistic rebellion.  But really who cares?  This all feels like an enormous waste of time.  Franco wasted his time writing this, the New York Times wasted time and space publishing it (though I suppose profit is reward enough for them) and I clearly wasted my time reading this and writing a response.  None of us should be proud of what has happened.

Danny Heim is exactly right.  Movers and shakers don't accomplish their effects by arguing with deniers or waiting for consensus.  They act.  If we think there's danger from climate change (and I sure do, thinking ahead a couple of centuries), we need to teach people about it and get some action.  Arguing won't do it.
There will be no adaptation unless we reduce emissions, because the environment we are trying to adapt to will get progressively worse.

I think of these innocent villagers - and land in the same family for all those centuries! then I realize, we're talking about 200-300 people. Wow, I hope Germany can figure something out fairly. Thank goodness they aren't plagued with as many lawyers shaking bushes for clients as we lucky people.

Last year's cost of litigation damage awards to the U.S. economy: $1,000 per person.

If it's right, just, compassionate, fair, appropriate, humane, or if just one of these applies, you can bet the Republicans are against it. For reasons of, principle, freedom, patriotism or any other lie they can come up with. Never the truth, that dinosaurs don't think, they react. Every change is viewed as a threat to their outmoded and rapacious status quo.

What a pity that Bob Dole is a liberal Democrat these days - at least according to the current Republican core voters.  If this trend of 20-year-old republican values being transmogrified into Communism, when Senator Ted Cruz is 90, his current beliefs will be characterized as far-left socialist rantings.  One shudders to think of the result.

Just thought I would show you how we keep warm up here, since the theme today is wood.
Nice solid smooth puzzle today, with Rubinstein playing a Chopin Nocturne!

Off topic - as a Canadian of Dutch heritage, I thought it was very nice and sporting of the Dutch speed skaters to let us have a couple of medals!
Ha ha!
Regards from Canada

"How much human-caused environmental destruction does it take to persuade deniers and the public that growth based capitalism is on a path to ecological collapse?"

Unfortunately, it's probably going to take an ecological collapse. Most people can barely see beyond the ends of their noses. When they do, they see television sets urging, admonishing and manipulating them into buying stuff, stuff and more stuff.

It is only when environmental services are no longer available that most people will begin to miss them…and by then it will be too late.

Why are we not better than this by now? This is not new news. We see videos like this often.

Where is the outrage?

The stimulus was too small. So is the raise.

More on both would be good for the economy, and all of us.

I like better:
Investment Banking | DealBook Column September 9, 2013, 8:34 pm
What Might Have Been, and the Fall of Lehman
By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN -

because at least Sorkin doesn't pretend to be a gambler - who knows it all.

I mean - what can you say about guys - who - if they are in some kind of a poker game - even don't know it?

The other talks do look interesting. Andy, have you asked the organizers if they plan on putting related material online?

https://scripps.ucsd.edu/sites/scripps.ucsd.edu/files/event/field_attach...

It's got to the point where doctors in China fear for their safety on a daily basis and regret their career choice. Most are poorly paid and face heavy workloads, up to 100 patients per day. The Chinese public have lost their respect for doctors because they face long waits and high fees in the current user-pays privatised health system under which hospitals receive little government funding. Tensions may ease as China's healthcare reforms take effect, including wider Medicare-style insurance cover and caps on medication prices.

It looks to me that we have moved from Big Brotherism to Gangsterism, whereby any group of tech-savvy mischief-makers decide to buck the system by making a nuisance of   the disciplined and legal use of technology. In the process, the very stability of civic governance, and civilization in general, becomes stultified.
And in the process of "sending a message," innocent people's lives get turned upside down.

It looks to me that we have moved from Big Brotherism to Gangsterism, whereby any group of tech-savvy mischief-makers decide to buck the system by making a nuisance of   the disciplined and legal use of technology. In the process, the very stability of civic governance, and civilization in general, becomes stultified.

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody:
I spoke with a lady named Martsynyuk tonight. She needed a translator. We spoke for a while. Her family lacks internet. We were connected by a first cousin of hers living in Brooklyn. I set up the conference call. I was not asked to do so.

The situation among the poor of the Ukraine is desperate. She says they will not cave to Russia or Russia's wishes. They seek a deeper connection to the West.

She said they sleep badly, are in tears all night, night after night. She said they will support the uprising. They fear Putin. They fear much blood will be shed. They feel this is the end if they do not prevail.

They do not have the money for an ISP connection.
Double synchronicity, John, with John Wooden and Drill Instructor [50D].

Jimmy Fallon is no Jay Leno, that's for sure. I get most of my news from John Stewart and Steve Colbert, but I almost rolled out of bed with laughter last night during The Tonight Show.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-YCeIgt7hMs

Wood only this made sense.

While I'm waiting for Martin to explain how Ray Walston made sense on Tuesday, maybe I'll saw through this puzzle.

I'm watching Jimmy Fallon and wondering how The Tonight Show is different rom the Jimmy Fallon Show, or Saturday Night Live, for that matter.

BUT as one actually is able to break down the whole dilemma to the cause of the whole mess -(gambling with houses) - dear Prof also could have asked: What should have been donne with the preverberal "homeowner" who financed his house 100 -(or 200?) percent.

Should he have been bailed out? - or left for the Blackstone (joke!) - corporation?

And isn't there always some "Blackstone" corporation?
And if the WHOLE thing would have been collapsed -
-("Frozen" - the movie!) - wouldn't it have been great if "the people" REALLY would have learned their lesson -
Or not? -
Because there is no other lesson then - afterwards there always is somebody, who picks up the pieces -(and makes a lot of dough with it)

Brave and patriotic Ukrainian citizens protest the  notorious corruption of Putin's puppet Mr Yanukovych who stoled billions from Ukrainian Treasury since 2010. His son is now the second richest oligarch in Ukraine. And you  worry about my Ukrainian Maidan being less than neat looking ? Would you complain about the American Revolution the same way?

Simple Math says, it shows how traumatized these countries were under Stalin's Regime, and the memory is still in the present population. The equation would have to say = Scared of Russia and/or the Oligarchs. -- Next Math problem? Maybe Russian population has to get into the act? And squash that bug forever. -- they are certainly known to stand up to their Political oppressors as well.

Ukraine already has been russified for decades by Russia. Ukrainian language and books were banned. Russian were sent to populate Eastern Ukraine.
Even the Russian puppet and thieving billionaire Yanukovych isn't ethnically Ukrainian!
